title: Question 25

children: A 68-year-old woman is evaluated for a 7-month history of insomnia. She has difficulty falling asleep and maintaining sleep. She is the primary caregiver for her 2 grandchildren following her daughter's recent death. Based on the STOP-BANG survey, she is at low risk for obstructive sleep apnea. PHQ-9 score is 3.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management of this patient's insomnia?
Cognitive behavioral therapy for insomnia is the most appropriate management for chronic insomnia in older adults.

Although cognitive behavioral therapy for insomnia (CBT-I) is first-line treatment for chronic insomnia, a short course of low-dose doxepin or a nonbenzodiazepine benzodiazepine receptor agonist can be considered in patients who are unable or unwilling to receive CBT-I.

) is the most appropriate next step in management. Insomnia symptoms are common in older patients, with up to 20% of adults older than 65 years meeting criteria for insomnia disorder. Prevalence is higher in women, especially those who are caregivers. Untreated insomnia has been associated with increased risk for depression, heart disease, and poorly controlled chronic comorbid conditions. Management should preferentially involve nonpharmacologic strategies. CBT-I is delivered in 6 to 10 sessions with a trained therapist and focuses on recognizing and eliminating behaviors that interfere with sleep. Studies support its efficacy in older adults, and it is recommended as first-line therapy by multiple guidelines.
Guidelines suggest against the use chamomile (

) for treatment of chronic insomnia disorder. A systematic review evaluated the efficacy and safety of valerian and chamomile for treatment of insomnia. There were no between-group differences in the critical outcomes of daytime functioning, insomnia severity, and sleep efficiency, and no differences in either daytime functioning or insomnia severity were found versus placebo.

) is a serotonin modulator. Current guidelines suggest against the use of trazodone for treatment of chronic insomnia disorder. A systematic review reported no differences in sleep efficiency or rate of discontinuation due to adverse events between trazodone and placebo in patients diagnosed with chronic insomnia. Cardiac arrhythmias, including prolonged QT interval on ECG and ventricular tachycardia, have been reported with trazodone as well as orthostatic hypotension, serotonin syndrome, and withdrawal syndrome.

The American College of Physicians recommends that physicians engage in a thorough shared decision-making process to decide whether to add pharmacologic therapy.
